Expectation1: Ensure client satisfaction and address any concerns or complaints professionally
Situation1: An easygoing regular politely asks for a tiny adjustment to their fringe.
Expectation2: Contribute to community well-being through paying taxes, following public health and safety guidance, and helping in emergencies
Situation2: Tax documents are organized a month before the deadline, and a free vaccine clinic runs this weekend at the community center.
Story: I was snipping away at Mrs. Lin’s fringe, enjoying our usual lighthearted banter, when she hesitated and asked if I could trim just a bit more. She’s always so polite, and I pride myself on making sure my clients leave happy, so I nodded and reached for my scissors. But as I sectioned her hair, my mind wandered to the envelope of tax documents waiting at home. I’d planned to finish them tonight, but then I remembered the vaccine clinic at the community center this weekend. They’re short on volunteers, and I know how important it is to help out, especially after last winter’s flu outbreak. I felt a knot in my stomach—my clients expect my full attention and care, but as a citizen, I should be pitching in for the greater good. The weight of these expectations pressed on me, and I found myself torn, scissors poised mid-air, wondering how I could possibly meet everyone’s needs at once.
